'''Gene Wolfe''' (born [[7 May|May 7]], [[1931]], died [[14 April|April 14]], [[2019]]) was an American author who primarily wrote fantasy fiction.

Wolfe corresponded with [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in the 1960s (see [[Letter 290a]]).<ref>Gene Wolfe, "The Best Introduction to the Mountains", in [[Interzone 174|''Interzone'', issue 174]], December 2001; see also [[Douglas A. Anderson]], ''[[The Annotated Hobbit: Revised and Expanded Edition]]'', pp. 146-7, note 9</ref> Tolkien appears to have read his short story, 'Trip, Trap', noting in [[Letter 297]] that the word 'warg' (on whose etymology Wolfe had consulted him) appeared in ''Orbit 2'', p. 119, in a story by 'a reader of the L.R.'
